name: 2-chloro-3,6-difluorophenol
Reason: 2-chloro-3,6-difluorophenol has a melting point that can be predicted by analyzing its functional groups. The basic unit of analysis is phenol, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The chlorine atom increases the molecular weight and size, which generally raises the melting point. The fluorine atoms, on the other hand, reduce the melting point due to their electronegativity and the resulting weakening of intermolecular hydrogen bonds. The chlorine atom can also participate in hydrogen bonding, which may slightly increase the melting point. The difluorophenol group can also contribute to the melting point due to its rigidity and increased molecular weight.
